title: WeWork to lay off a QUARTER of its 12,500 workforce to reduce costs
text:
Coworking startup WeWork plans to lay off up to a quarter of its workforce following the ouster of CEO Adam Neumann, according to a new report.

WeWork plans layoffs 'in the thousands', though less than the 3,000 to 5,000 number that had been previously reported, a person familiar with the matter told Business Insider.

The company has 12,500 employees, so a cut of 1,000 to 3,000 people would be about 10% to 25% of its staff.

Following backlash from investors over a dubious business model, Neumann stepped down last month, and new CEOs Artie Minson and Sebastian Gunningham put plans for an initial public offering on hold.

New WeWork CEOs Sebastian Gunningham (left) and Artie Minson (right) put plans for an initial public offering on hold, and are reportedly planning layoffs

Founding CEO Adam Neumann (above) was outsted last month after investors rebelled

On Thursday, the new CEOs met with employees and told them that layoffs would be forthcoming as a cost control measure, according to Bloomberg.

WeWork, whose parent We Company lost $1.9 billion in 2018, had hoped to raise at least $3 billion in the abandoned IPO and borrow a further $6 billion in a loan from banks that was contingent on the listing.

Monday's decision to scrap the IPO marked the conclusion of a tumultuous few weeks for WeWork, which failed to excite investors who raised concerns about its ballooning losses and a business model that involves taking long-term leases and renting out spaces for a short term.

Minson and Gunningham have talked about the need to return to WeWork's core business of renting out trendy office space to freelancers and enterprises.

That would pull the company back from the fringe activities Neumann had forayed into, such as education.

A WeWork office is seen in New York City on July 19. WeWork, which replaced its controversial chief executive last week, announced that it will withdraw a plan to go public

Global credit rating agency Fitch Ratings on Tuesday downgraded WeWork's credit rating by two notches to 'CCC+', putting the Softbank-backed office-sharing firm deep into junk territory

Fellow ratings agency Standard & Poor's last week downgraded WeWork to 'B-' from 'B'.

Both 'CCC+' and 'B-' are junk bond ratings reserved for corporate borrowers judged to be higher risk to lenders.

WeWork is in discussions with banks as well as its largest investor SoftBank Corp about potential alternative funding, two sources familiar with the matter told Reuters on Monday.

The backlash against the startup unfolded after the company's huge losses were revealed in its prospectus filing for an IPO.

CEO Adam Neumann and his wife Rebekah Paltrow Neumann are pictured last April. She produced WeWork's S-1 and, insiders say, treated it like the 'September issue of Vogue'

Among WeWork's expenses was a Gulfstream jet the company paid $60million for and to have it redesigned inside. A file image of the style of jet he bought is shown

It revealed, among other things, WeWork's huge losses ($1.6 billion) which sent investor faith and public opinion of the company plummeting.

It also raised questions about ousted Neumann's potential conflicts of interest and his ability to lead.

Until then, the company had relied on public image and buzz to boost its reputation. It was valued at $47billion - a 'ridiculous' sum by some analysts' measures.

Among complaints from staffers was that Neumann charged ahead prematurely with the IPO when he should have been focusing on the company's growth.

Some also criticized him for bringing in his wife, Rebekah Paltrow Neumann, to produce the S-1 - a regulatory form that all companies must submit when they apply to go public.

The introduction to WeWork's S-1 is shown above. The sleek, image-heavy document did not fall in line with the normal format followed by companies when submitting their financials

This is one of the pages from the S-1 which Neumann's wife produced with the help of a creative director and professional photographers. She featured celebrities like Anna Faris in the document and quoted her gushing about the office space she could rent. The glossy, magazine-like S-1 did not fail to disguise the company's huge losses, however

Normally a standard regulatory filing, in WeWork's case the S-1 was a glossy, pitch-deck like portfolio which featured celebrities and Instagram influencers including Anna Faris and Aimee Song.

It showcased the company's offices and touted the 'amenities' clients' got with them - flavored water, micro-roasted coffee, cleaning, and 'craft on draft' beer.

Insiders said the way Neumann handled the document was typical of WeWork - to focus not on the point of it, which was to prove the company's financial viability, but to jazz it up.

It also cast Neumann's astronomic spending in new light. In recent years, the young former CEO has amassed an $80million property portfolio.

He also bought a Gulfstream jet and personalized it to the tune of $65million. Before he was ousted, the company announced plans to sell it.
description: WeWork plans layoffs 'in the thousands', though less than the 3,000 to 5,000 number that had been previously reported, a person familiar with the matter told Business Insider .
